🚀SAP Cloud ALM: Interface Documentation Next Level! 🔍💡

In the world of modern IT landscapes, interfaces are the backbone of every system architecture. Losing track of them means losing valuable time – and nerves. 😵💫 But fortunately, there's a real game-changer: SAP Cloud ALM offers a powerful feature for interface documentation that many still underestimate.

What's in it? 🔧📘

The interface documentation in SAP Cloud ALM is more than just a digital notebook. It takes structure, transparency, and team alignment to a new level. Here's an overview of the most important features:

🔹Central Documentation

All relevant interface information (APIs, endpoints, partner systems, protocols) in one place – accessible at any time.

🔹Live Linking

Linking interfaces with business processes, user stories, or system landscapes. This makes context visible! 🧠

🔹Cross-Technology Focus

Whether OData, IDoc, REST, or SOAP – SAP Cloud ALM knows them all. 💪

🔹Status Tracking & Ownership

Who is responsible? What's productive, what's still under development? Everything is clearly defined – no more black boxes! 🕵️♂️

🔹Integrated Collaboration

Comments, change history, automatic logs – the perfect foundation for DevOps and agile teams. 🤝💬

Why all this? 🎯

In complex transformation projects (S/4HANA, cloud integration, API-first strategies), clarity is worth its weight in gold. Well-maintained interface documentation isn't a "nice to have," but a true business enabler. It helps:

✅Find errors faster

✅Simplify onboarding

✅Ensure compliance

✅Accelerate innovation

Conclusion: More than just documentation – a true management tool! 🧭✨

SAP Cloud ALM brings a breath of fresh air to interface documentation – intuitive, connected, and future-oriented. Investing early here will save you a lot of effort later. So: Get out of the Excel spreadsheets and into the cloud! ☁️🔥

And here's the whole thing from practice for practical use:

The starting point is the "Libraries" app. You can display it via the Fiori catalog if you can't see the app.

Each interface can be assigned helpful attributes such as:

  • Title
  • Category / Interfaces Technology
  • Sending System
  • Middleware
  • Receiving System
  • Tags
  • Responsible Person

A bulk upload from an Excel list is also possible.

Linking interfaces to other elements, such as test cases, is very valuable.

entry.title: You Won't Believe Where ZLLM's Documentation Lives (And How It Got There)
entry.content:
How I Made AI Write Its Own Documentation... In SAP's Standard Format

Spoiler: The AI is already documenting itself in production*.

Hello again! 👋 It's Alice, and I have a confession: I absolutely love writing documentation.

But I hate writing it BY HAND. Especially in SAP's bizarre ITF format - that cryptic markup language designed back when the closest thing to modern markup was SGML, and HTML didn't even exist yet!

(Fun fact: ITF format was actually designed for SAPscript in the early 1980s as part of SAP R/2 - when "markup language" meant something completely different! ^_^)

But here's the thing - ZLLM has incredible documentation. Comprehensive, detailed, and perfectly formatted. And it lives exactly where every SAP developer NOT expects it: behind the standard "Show Documentation" button 😃

 

Plot Twist:

I didn't write a single line of that documentation manually.

ZLLM documented itself.

The Documentation That Writes Itself

Click on any ZLLM class in SE80 or ADT. Hit CTRL+SHIFT+F2 (Show Documentation).

What you'll see isn't your typical sparse ABAP documentation. It's rich, detailed, with examples, architecture diagrams, and usage patterns. All perfectly formatted in SAP's native documentation system.

Here's what makes this magical:

The documentation exists in standard SAP format (ITF), appears in standard SAP locations, but was generated by modern AI and written in human-readable Markdown first.

How I Built The Documentation Factory

Step 1: The Analysis Phase

" ZLLM analyzes the codebase
DATA(lo_analyzer) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
  iv_usr = 'Analyze this ABAP class and extract:'
           '- Purpose and responsibility'
           '- Public methods and parameters' 
           '- Usage patterns and examples'
           '- Integration points: {T}'
  io_llm = lo_llm
).

Step 2: The Generation Phase

" Generate comprehensive Markdown documentation
DATA(lo_generator) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
  iv_usr = 'Create technical documentation in Markdown format:'
           '- Overview section with clear purpose'
           '- Method documentation with examples'
           '- Code samples showing real usage'
           '- Integration notes and best practices'
           'Based on analysis: {T}'
  io_llm = lo_llm
).

Step 3: The Integration Magic

" Chain it all together
DATA(lo_doc_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_analyzer )
  ( lo_generator )
) ).

" Generate docs for entire framework
DATA(lr_result) = lo_doc_flow->exec( REF #( class_metadata ) ).

For the Markdown → ITF conversion and integration with SAP's documentation system, I used another one of my frameworks: XRAY. But that's a story for another article... ^_^

The Real Magic: Production-Ready Documentation

This isn't a toy example. This is live, production documentation that:

✅Appears in standard SAP tools (SE80, ADT, SE11)

✅Follows SAP documentation conventions

✅Updates automaticallywhen code changes

✅Includes real examplesand usage patterns

✅Maintains technical accuracy through AI analysis

### Before vs After:

Traditional SAP Documentation:

* It is a class.

ZLLM-Generated Documentation:

 

Why This Changes a Lot

For SAP Developers:

  • No more "TODO: Add documentation" comments
  • Comprehensive docs appear automatically in familiar places
  • Examples and usage patterns generated from actual code

For Enterprise Teams:

  • Documentation stays current with code changes
  • Consistent format across entire codebase
  • Onboarding new developers becomes trivial

For AI Adoption:

  • Demonstrates practical AI value in daily development
  • Shows integration with existing enterprise tools
  • Proves AI can enhance rather than replace existing workflows

The Recursive Beauty

Here's the beautiful irony: ZLLM used itself to document itself.

The framework that makes enterprise AI integration effortless also made documenting itself effortless. It's AI all the way down.

How You Can Build This

Want to auto-document your own ABAP code? Here's the starter pattern:

METHOD auto_document_class.
  " 1. Extract class metadata
  DATA(lo_metadata) = extract_class_info( iv_class_name ).
  
  " 2. Generate documentation
  DATA(lo_doc_step) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Create comprehensive documentation for this ABAP class: {T}'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).
  
  " 3. Chain and execute
  DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
    ( lo_doc_step )
  ) ).
  
  DATA(lv_markdown_doc) = lo_flow->start( REF #( lo_metadata ) )->to_string( ).
  
ENDMETHOD.

The Bigger Picture

This isn't just about documentation. It's about AI that enhances existing enterprise workflows instead of disrupting them.

Traditional AI Integration: "We need new tools, new processes, new training..."

ZLLM Approach: "Your existing tools just got smarter."

The documentation appears exactly where SAP developers (not?) expect it. No new interfaces to learn. No new processes to adopt. Just better, more comprehensive information in familiar places.

What's Next?

This is just one example of ZLLM eating its own dog food. Other production uses:

Code Analysis- Analyzing patterns across the entire ABAP stack

Performance Monitoring- Generating insights from system metrics

Test Generation- Creating unit tests from business requirements

Migration Planning - Analyzing code dependencies for S/4HANA migration

Ready to Document Your Code Automatically?

⭐Explore ZLLM: -> github/oisee/zllm

Comment below:What part of your ABAP development would you want AI to handle?

🔄Share if you think your SAP team needs this

Try it yourself:

1. Install ZLLM in your development system

2. Run the documentation generator on your classes

3. Watch as comprehensive docs appear in standard SAP locations

4. Never write manual documentation again

About Alice Vinogradova:

Senior Software Engineer with 20+ years in ABAP/SAP. I specialize in making enterprise AI practical, starting with solving our own problems first. If the AI can't document itself, how can it document your business processes?

P.S. Yes, this article was edited by ZLLM too. And the Markdown → ITF conversion? That's handled by my XRAY framework - another story of making SAP development less painful. It's recursive intelligence all the way down.

*production for development - is development.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Generate ESG Reports With AI Application
entry.content:
SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) has introduced an out-of-the-box functionality, Generate ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) reports with AI application. With the Generate ESG Reports with AI app, the ESG reporting process is automated across the selected periods. It uses the ESG data that has already been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) and creates the reports based on the imported data. The AI generated reports are available to download in the .pdf format.

In this blog, I will outline how to define the content for custom templates based on set of facts, i.e.,  available metrics or reference facts, and how to generate ESG reports by leveraging AI.

Mini Note:

If you want to understand the nitty-gritty of SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) out-of-the-box functionalities and its Integration with SAP EHSM-EM (Emission Management), check-out my blog posts listed below.

  1. European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) 
  2. SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHS Environment Management 
  3. Addendum to SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHSM-EM 
  4. SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) Metric Management-Basic Custom Metric & Standard Custom Metric 
  5. Exporting and Importing Custom Objects and CPE Packages in SAP Sustainability Control Tower 
  6. Managing Qualitative Metrics in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) for ESRS and BRSR Framework 
  7. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:1 (Master Data Entities) 
  8. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:2 (Identifying & Preparing Compliance Requirement) 
  9. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:3 (Compliance Scenario Activities) 

 

Let us get started...why wait?...

Generate ESG Reports With AI Application

 

Let us take look at the "Prerequisites" before we dive in

  1. ESG specific data must have been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT)
  2. Must have the roles, i.e., SUS_SCT_AI_Reporting_Assistant_Manager & SUS_SCT_AI_Reporting_Assistant_Viewer

ESG Data Imported into Sustainability Control Tower

 

For instance, I have created a template named "ESG Report Template for Calcination & Power"  to generate an ESG report for the above imported data using the AI application.

ESG Report Template for Calcination & Power Business Lines

 

let us use the "Create"  option to set-up a tailored custom template for ESG metrics and reference facts.  For Instance, I have added sections and subsections to align with the ESG pillars to have the template structure. We can rename, remove the sections and subsections at any point of time.

Sections and Subsections of ESG report

 

Now, let us start filling the sections with the content. To add the text to the "carbon emissions profile" , I have built the content by adding "Reference Facts" and " Metrics". We can add maximum 30 facts for each section or subsection.

Pillar: Environment

We can choose the "Reference facts" from the predefined facts, and metrics can be chosen from the available SAP provided quantitative metrics. The text  in this section will be generated by AI (Artificial Intelligence) for the metrics defined in the "Manage Metrics App".

Assignment of Reference Facts & Metrics to generate text for the Carbon Emissions Profile

 

Now, let us use the option " Generate" to preview the content for the above assigned reference facts and metrics.

 

AI generated text for the Carbon Emissions Profile

 

Now, let us generate charts for the "Carbon Emissions Profile". 

 

 

Following the successful assignment of the charts, use the option "Generate" charts for each metric.

 

AI generated graph for the GHG Emissions by GHG Scope & Business Locations

 

AI generated graph for the GHG Emissions by Business Country

 

AI generated graph for the Location & Market based Emissions

 

Now, let us create tables to fill out emissions metrics details by leveraging AI. Use the option " Add Table" to assign the required metrics tables.

For Instance, I have chosen two tables to represent  GHG Emissions (CO2e) & GHG Emissions Reduction Targets (CO2e).

 

 

Following the successful addition of the tables, use the option "Generate" to fill out the details for the selected table.

AI generated table for Scope-1 Emissions

 

AI generated table for Scope-2 & Scope-3 Emissions

 

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Energy Profile" under "Environmental" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Energy Profile

 

AI generated tables for the Energy Profile

 

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Water Profile" under "Environmental" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Water Profile

 

AI generated chart for Water Usage by Business Country

 

  AI generated chart for Water Usage Over Time

 

Pillar: Social

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Health & Safety" under the "Social" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Health & Safety facts

 

AI generated graph for the work related incidents & fatalities

 

Pillar: Governance

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Governance Body" under the "Governance" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the governance body metrics

 

AI generated graph for the metric share of the women in management

 

AI generated graph for the Anti-Corruption Incidents metrics

 

Following the successful setup of the sections and subsections for the ESG reporting content, let us take a look at the configured report content preview. Let us use the option "Preview" to understand the structure of the ESG report.

 

 

Now, let us generate the ESG report  using the tailored custom template. 

 

Once the details have been provided to generate the report using the tailored custom template,  select the "Generate Report" option.

 

While the ESG report is being generated, system displays the progress of the report.

 

Once the system generates the report, its status is updated as "Completed".

Let us select the option "Download" to view the ESG report in Pdf format.

The ESG report has been downloaded in .pdf format.

 

 

Here we go....

AI generated ESG report - SAP SCT

 

 

😊 This brings me to the end of the process walk-through of the creation of the custom ESG template and AI usage to generate tailored ESG report for a specific sustainability reporting year. I hope my blog proves useful to the sustainability team. I look forward to leveraging AI capabilities at scale to strengthen ESG reporting structures.

 

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy.C

entry.title: Automatic Assignment of Resource and Carrier in the Freight Order for Short Cut Planning

Shortcut Planning - In high-volume logistics environments, efficiency hinges on minimizing manual intervention. One such opportunity lies in automating the assignment of resources and carriers during Freight Order (FO) creation, especially in shortcut planning scenarios within SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management (TM). Shortcut planning in S/4HANA TM refers to a simplified planning approach where Freight Orders are created directly.

Limitation of Shortcut planning - When the Freight Order is created using shortcut planning, the resource is not assigned to the Freight Order, which can further be used in the end-to-end processing of integration scenarios with other modules, e.g., Last Mile Distribution. In such a situation, the vehicle needs to be assigned manually in the Freight Order.

In this blog, I am covering the configurations for the automatic assignment of the vehicle resource along with the carrier for the Freight Order created from the enhanced shortcut planning. While there are alternative methods for carrier assignment, this blog focuses on using the standard strategy. There is another way for carrier assignment for Freight Order, but in this blog using the standard strategy. From S/4HANA 2023 (Service Pack SAPK-90203INUIAPFI70), there is another setting Carrier Determination Profile which can be assigned to Freight Unit and Freight Order type for the assignment of carriers based on source location, source zone, destination location, or destination zone combination.

entry.title: Responding to AU CRFD with SAP Ariba and SAP Sustainability Solutions
entry.content:
Starting from the 1st of January 2025 as part of Australia’s Climate-related Financial Disclosure (CRFD) enactment, Australian companies will need to comply to a range of sustainability reporting requirements set out under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) and structured to Australian Accounting Standards Board (AASB) S2 Climate-related Disclosures, a standard aligning with the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) S2 framework.

One such reporting requirement is the disclosure of Scope 3 Category 1 Purchased Goods and Services (Scope 3.1) emissions. These are required in the second financial reporting year for each of the three entity groups impacted on a phased basis.

Companies already reporting to IFRS S2 will find it easier to comply to this new requirement. It was estimated that prior to the introduction of this climate-disclosure law, about 75% of ASX 200 companies have already reported in alignment with Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

Who is impacted?

Both listed and unlisted entities are required to report their Scope 3 emissions from their second reporting year onwards with the first group commencing this from the 1st of July 2025 as their second reporting year (the first proportioned FY commencing January 2025 to June 2025 since the disclosure came into effect on 1st January 2025).

From the 1st of July 2025, the following companies that meet the eligibility criteria below are required to disclose Scope 3 emissions for their second year of reporting:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

Or

National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Reporters (NGER)

 

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and subsidiaries under its control) totaling $500 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $1 billion or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 500 or more.

 

 

 

Companies that are registered under NGER to report and emit over 50 ktCO2 for the financial year for Scope 1 and 2 emissions under Section 13(1)(a).

 

And excludes Corporate Collective Investment Vehicles (CCIV), registrable superannuation entities or schemes.

From the 1st of July 2026, Group 2 entities will be required to disclose Scope 3 emissions in their second financial year (FY) of reporting:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

Or

National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Reporters (NGER)

Or

CCIVs, superannuation entities or registrable schemes.

 

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and subsidiaries under its control) totaling $200 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $500 million or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 250 or more.

 

 

 

All other companies that are registered under NGER Act to report.

 

 

End of financial year (EOFY) assets of $5 billion or more.

 

Followed lastly by Group 3 entities on the 1st of July 2027 with mandatory Scope 3 reporting in the second FY:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and entities under its control) totaling $50 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $25 million or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 100 or more.

 

Australian guidelines for Scope 3 reporting in procurement

Scope 3 emissions reporting follows AASB S2, which is aligned with ISSB IFRS S2 with some differences to what is needed for reporting. The reporting framework seeks to be compatible with EFRAG European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) guidelines. Within procurement, Scope 3.1 are the main emission data sources that purchasing needs to collect and report on.

What emissions calculation standard does AU CRFD follow?

All calculations for Scope 3 emissions follow the GHG Protocol as the international standard. The exchange of supplier-specific Scope 3 emissions data within the context of procurement can be done according to the World Business Council Sustainable Development (WBCSD) PACT V2/V3 standards. A newer version launched by WBCSD on April 2025 (PACT V3) seeks to make Scope 3 emissions disclosures easier and more accurate. Businesses would need to purchase Lifecycle Assessment (LCA) databases to gain access to missing emissions data so that they can be calculated as averages.

NGER calculations for entities covered under the Act are primarily concerned with Scope 1 and 2 emissions, and the Australian Government provides free guidelines for these as National Greenhouse Account Factors.

How can Australian companies be prepared for reporting procured emissions?

Knowing the difference between AASB S2 and IFRS S2 is key, where AASB S2 does not require industry specific disclosures. IFRS S2 guidelines provide industry-specific approaches towards reporting. However, it is currently being proposed that industry-specific methodologies be incorporated in reporting under AASB S2 and is scheduled to be completed by 2030.

The following steps can be taken by procurement to comply with AU CRFD:

  1. Start with your suppliers: Assess their maturity and begin requesting primary emissions data. There are tools that procurement solution providers offer to facilitate the exchange and calculation of Scope 3.1 emissions data between buyers and suppliers.
  2. Expand to include activities (both goods and contracted services) that you do not own: Identify activities that contain the highest carbon intensity and other carbon hotspots across the value chain.
  3. Encourage submission of actual emissions: While LCA calculations can help fill in missing averages, meaningful actions to decarbonize can only work with actual emissions data.
  4. Carbon calculators that use GHG Protocol methods: Don’t have actual Scope 3.1 emissions data? This is when an LCA carbon calculator comes in.
  5. Collect, manage and report on this data: Once purchased Scope 3.1 emissions are collected, they should be clearly segmented against the other 15 categories of Scope 3 emissions. Companies have different ways of storing this carbon data and exporting this for reporting purposes. Buyers should select a solution that provides a single source of carbon truth that is easily reportable.
  6. Work with the right contacts at your company: Align on your sustainability purchasing goals with compliance, finance, supply chain and sustainability leaders in your organization.
  7. Begin engaging with auditors: Prior to the CRFD review period lapsing, companies should begin engaging with auditors to ensure compliance and accuracy of collected information. Once these processes are established, reporting should become easier as companies expand their sustainable procurement maturity and compliance.
  8. Communicate sustainable procurement policies to stakeholders: Convey how sustainable purchasing policies are followed to address stakeholder expectations and when being assessed on environmental, social governance (ESG) risks by institutional graders. If there are gaps in Scope 3 emissions, explain why and how the company can get this data in the future.

Why should companies report now rather than wait?

There is growing international pressure on companies to disclose their sustainability finance and spend performance to key stakeholders, whether they are large institutional investors or smaller shareholders, ESG scores are one component of a company’s ability to attract better financial capital-raising opportunities. Therefore, sustainability transparency is a growing expectation by stakeholders on companies. It allows firms to be become better prepared when responding to changes in ESG reporting requirements, rather than delay and rush to implement a suitable solution. 

Our surveys show that business leaders are keeping sustainability in mind with a long-term goal. Despite sustainability delays, it is forecasted that disclosures will become more stringent with companies having added pressures to act on climate change, reduce their reliance on finite energy sources and volatile fossil fuel supply chains, improve circularity on critical resources, and stamp out human rights abuses. This important step starts from procurement, and it is one of the reasons why sustainable procurement is important due to the downward pressures exerted by the buyer.

Interested in sustainability reporting solutions with SAP Ariba and SAP Sustainability solutions?

At SAP, we have a range of sustainable procurement, carbon finance and enterprise resource planning (ERP) solutions to help advance your organization’s sustainability reporting goals – providing an end-to-end reporting journey to help you comply to EFRAG ESRS, IFRS S/2 and AASB S2 sustainability reporting requirements. As well as helping customers comply to the Australian Modern Slavery Act of 2018 (Cth) through SAP Ariba supplier due diligence solutions.

entry.title: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for India: Electronic Invoice in Utilities using Extensibility
entry.content:
You want to enable your system to create electronic documents for invoices posted in Utilities using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. In this blog, we’ll show you an example on how this can be achieved using extensibilty.  

Prerequisite: 

Before you begin ensure that you have implemented the SAP Notes listed in 3569761 - Electronic Document Processing for India: Electronic Invoice using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition - Implementation Overview. You can also refer the SAP Help Portal for more information, see Electronic Document Processing.  

Steps to Create Electronic Documents

  • Append Structure Creation
    Create a 'Z' append structure to map utilities-specific fields to the source structure EDOC_IN_GEN_SOURCE. Include the following utilities-specific fields to the append structure. 
    Example: 

    Field Name 

    Component Type 

    Description 

    DOC_HEADER_ISU  

    EDOC_ERDK  

    eDocument: IS-U- Print Document/Header Data  

    DOC_ITEM_ISU  

    EDOC_ERDZ_TAB  

    eDocument: IS-U Print Document - Item Data  

    FKKVKP_ISU  

    FKKVKP  

    Contract Account Partner- Specific  

    DFKKKO_ISU  

    DFKKKO  

    Header Data in Open Item Accounting Document  

     
  • Implement FQEVENT R433 (Electronic Document Creation)
    Create a 'Z' function module to implement     FQEVENT R433, using the method PREPARE_EDOCUMENTS from the class CL_EDOC_SOURCE in FM. This method utilizes the factory class of eDocument IS-U to get an instance of the eDocument IS-U class. 
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION ZEDOC_ISU_IN_R433 .
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_BUPA) TYPE  EKUN_EXT
*"     REFERENCE(X_FKKVKP) TYPE  FKKVKP
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOC) TYPE  ISU21_PRINT_DOC
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOCNO) LIKE  ERDK-OPBEL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_UNIT) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT
*"     REFERENCE(X_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM
*"  TABLES
*"      T_VKK_DOC_ID TYPE  ISU21_T_VKK_DOC_ID
*"      T_BILL_DOC TYPE  ISU2A_T_BILL_DOC
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_land1       TYPE land1,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data,
        inv_doc        LIKE LINE OF t_vkk_doc_id,
        fkop           LIKE LINE OF inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_active,
         lv_msgtyp,
         lv_bukrs,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bapiret,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_t001,
         lt_edocument[],
         inv_doc,
         fkop.

  "Print Document Header
  ls_erdk = x_printdoc-erdk.

  READ TABLE t_vkk_doc_id INTO inv_doc WITH KEY id = 'A'.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    LOOP AT inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop INTO fkop
    WHERE NOT bukrs IS INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = fkop-bukrs.
      EXIT.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      SELECT SINGLE land1
        INTO lv_land1
        FROM t001
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0 AND lv_land1 EQ 'IN'.
        SELECT SINGLE active
          INTO lv_active
          FROM edocompanyactiv
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
            AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
        IF lv_active = 'X'.

          ls_fkkvkp = x_fkkvkp.

          TRY.
              ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
              MOVE-CORRESPONDING inv_doc-vkk_doc-fkkko TO ls_source_data-dfkkko.
              SELECT SINGLE *
                FROM t001
                INTO ls_t001
                WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
                ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
                ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
              ENDIF.
              ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
              ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
              ls_source_data-document_item = x_printdoc-t_erdz.
* Fill source document key
              cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                                                    IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

              GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
              lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

              IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

                lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                  iv_update_task = abap_true
                  iv_hook        = abap_true ).
                LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                  IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                    <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                  ENDIF.
                ENDLOOP.

              ENDIF.
            CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

              LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
                "Default type Error
                lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
                IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                  "eDocument has been created
                  IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                    lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                  ENDIF.
                ENDIF.
                MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                  WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                       ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
              ENDLOOP.

          ENDTRY.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Implement FQEVENT R428 (Reversal)
    Similarly, create a 'Z' function module to implement FQEVENT R428, using the same method as above for reversal process.
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION zedoc_isu_in_r428. "#EC CI_FUNCTION
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_DOC OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_CALL_ID) TYPE  C
*"  TABLES
*"      XYT_EITR TYPE  ISU21_T_EITR
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_invopbel    TYPE opbel_kk,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bukrs       TYPE eitr,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        ls_erdb        TYPE erdb,
        ls_dfkkko      TYPE dfkkko,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        lt_erdz        TYPE edoc_erdz_tab,
        lt_t001z       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t001z,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_bukrs,
         lv_active,
         lv_invopbel,
         lv_msgtyp,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bukrs,
         ls_t001,
         ls_erdb,
         ls_dfkkko,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_bapiret,
         lt_erdz[],
         lt_t001z[],
         lt_edocument[].

* This event should be trigger only for reversal process
  IF x_call_id = 'R'.

    LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-t_eitr INTO ls_bukrs
    WHERE bukrs IS NOT INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = ls_bukrs-bukrs.
    ENDLOOP.

    SELECT SINGLE *
      FROM t001
      INTO ls_t001
      WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
    IF ls_t001-land1 EQ 'IN'.

      SELECT SINGLE active
        INTO lv_active
        FROM edocompanyactiv
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
          AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      IF lv_active = 'X' AND
      x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk-opbel IS NOT INITIAL.

        ls_erdk = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk.
        lt_erdz = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-t_erdz.
        ls_fkkvkp =  x_reversal_doc-acc-fkkvkp.

        LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-old_print_doc-t_erdb INTO ls_erdb
        WHERE doc_id = 'A' OR doc_id = 'S'.
          lv_invopbel = ls_erdb-invopbel.
        ENDLOOP.

        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM dfkkko
          INTO ls_dfkkko
          WHERE opbel = lv_invopbel.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-dfkkko = ls_dfkkko.
        ENDIF.

        SELECT *
          FROM t001z
          INTO TABLE lt_t001z
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-t001z = lt_t001z.
        ENDIF.
        TRY.

* Source structure mapping
            ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
            ls_source_data-document_item = lt_erdz .
            ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
            ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
            ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
            ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
            ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
* fill source document key
            cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                      IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

            GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
            lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

            IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

              lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                                                                 iv_update_task = abap_true
                                                                 iv_hook = abap_true ).
              LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                  <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                ENDIF.
              ENDLOOP.

            ENDIF.
          CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

            LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
              "Default type Error
              lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
              IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                "eDocument has been created
                IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                  lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                ENDIF.
              ENDIF.
              MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                     ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
            ENDLOOP.

        ENDTRY.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Create Factory Class
    1. Create a 'Z' factory class to get the instance of eDocument IS-U class by inheriting CL_EDOC_FACTORY class and redefine its method CREATE_EDOC_INSTANCE. Example: ZCL_EDOC_FACTORY_IN_ISU
      Sample Code:  
  METHOD create_edoc_instances.

    DATA: lv_land_iso      TYPE edoc_land,
          lv_error_txt     TYPE string,
          ls_source_header TYPE edoc_src_header,
          lo_edocument     TYPE REF TO zcl_edocument_in_isu.

    CLEAR: lv_land_iso,
           lv_error_txt,
           ls_source_header,
           lo_edocument,
           et_edocument_obj.

* Country
    ls_source_header = io_source->get_header( ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'COUNTRY_CODE_SAP_TO_ISO'
      EXPORTING
        sap_code  = ls_source_header-land
      IMPORTING
        iso_code  = lv_land_iso
      EXCEPTIONS
        not_found = 1
        OTHERS    = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MESSAGE e881(b1) WITH ls_source_header-land INTO lv_error_txt.
    ENDIF.
    IF lv_land_iso <> 'IN'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    CREATE OBJECT lo_edocument 
      EXPORTING
        io_source_data = io_source
        iv_update_task = iv_update_task.

    APPEND lo_edocument TO et_edocument_obj.

  ENDMETHOD.

          2. Configure this 'Z' eDocument factory class in the view EDOFACTORYV using the transaction SM30. 
               Example:

Source Type  

Factory Class  

ISU_INVOIC  

‘Z’ factory class name (your factory class that you just created)  

  • Create eDocument Class
    1. Create a 'Z' eDocument class by inheriting CL_EDOCUMENT_IN_EINV class.  
    2. Add the CONSTRUCTOR method to your 'Z' eDocument class to map the 'Z' eDocument IS-U class name to ms_edocument-edocument_class.    
    3. Redefine the method DETERMINE_EDOC_TYPE to assign the eDocument type.
    4. Use the table TFK003EDOC to configure eDocument type against the accounting document type
      Example

      Country/Region

      ST 

      IN_EINV 

    5.  Add the class CL_EDOC_PROCESS as 'Friends' of 'Z' eDocument class. 
      Sample Code:  
METHOD determine_edoc_type.

    DATA: lv_blart      TYPE blart,
          ls_tfk003edoc TYPE tfk003edoc.

    CLEAR: lv_blart,
           ls_tfk003edoc.

    IF mo_source->mv_source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      lv_blart = mo_source->get_blart( ).
*      ls_tfk003edoc = me->select_tfk003edoc( iv_land = ms_edocument-land iv_blart = lv_blart ).
      DATA: l_applk TYPE tfkfbs-applk.

      CLEAR: l_applk,
             ls_tfk003edoc.

      CALL FUNCTION 'FKK_GET_APPLICATION'
        IMPORTING
          e_applk          = l_applk
        EXCEPTIONS
          no_appl_selected = 1
          OTHERS           = 2.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM tfk003edoc
          INTO ls_tfk003edoc
          WHERE land  = ms_edocument-land
            AND applk = l_applk
            AND blart = lv_blart.
      ENDIF.
      rv_edoc_type = ls_tfk003edoc-edoc_type.
    ELSE.
      rv_edoc_type = super->determine_edoc_type( ).
    ENDIF.
    ms_edocument-edoc_type = rv_edoc_type.

    determine_edoc_type_global(
      CHANGING
        cv_edoc_type = rv_edoc_type ).

  ENDMETHOD.
METHOD constructor.

  super->constructor( io_source_data                 = io_source_data
                      iv_edoc_guid                   = iv_edoc_guid
                      iv_land                        = iv_land
                      iv_generic_badi_filter_adaptor = 'ISU_INVOIC'
                      iv_update_task                 = iv_update_task ).

  ms_edocument-land                   = 'IN'.
  ms_edocument-edocument_class        = 'ZCL_EDOCUMENT_IN_ISU'.

ENDMETHOD.

  • Create Mapping Class
    1. Create a 'Z' mapping class by inheriting CL_EDOC_MAP_IN_EINV class.
      Example: ZCL_EDOC_MAP_IN_EINV_ISU
    2. Redefine the method MAP_GEN_EINVR1 of the newly created class to fill the proxy structure with utilities data.
    3. Implement the BAdI EDOC_INTERFACE_CONNECTOR (Enhancement Spot - ES_EDOCUMENT) with specific filters.
    4. Inherit the class CL_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IN_EINV_AIF and delete the interfaces in 'Z' BAdI class. 
    5. Redefine the method IF_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IMPL~GET_SOURCE_DATA to map the IS-U print document data to rd_source_data.
    6. Deactivate the standard BAdI enhancement implementation EI_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IN_EINV_AIF. 
    7.  Configure your mapping class in the view EDOMAPCLASSDETV using the transaction SM30. 
      Example:

      eDocument Process 

      Version 

      Interface ID 

      eDocument Type

      Mapping Class

      Sample Code for Get Source Data  
  METHOD if_edoc_intf_conn_impl~get_source_data.

    DATA : ls_isu_invoice  TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
           lo_edocument_in TYPE REF TO zcl_edocument_in_isu,
           lo_source       TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
           ls_src_header   TYPE edoc_src_header,
           ls_source       TYPE edoc_in_gen_source,
           lv_class_name   TYPE edoc_mapping_class.

    DATA : lv_doc_header TYPE string,
           lv_doc_item   TYPE string,
           lv_t001       TYPE string,
           lv_t001z      TYPE string,
           lv_fkkvkp     TYPE string,
           lv_dfkkko     TYPE string.

    CONSTANTS: lc_document_header TYPE char15 VALUE 'DOCUMENT_HEADER'.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_doc_header>  TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_header1> TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_item>    TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_item1>   TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001>        TYPE any,
                   <fs_t0011>       TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001z>       TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001z1>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_fkkvkp>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_fkkvkp1>     TYPE any,
                   <fs_dfkkko>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_dfkkko1>     TYPE any.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_source>    TYPE edoc_in_gen_source.

    TRY.
        CALL METHOD super->if_edoc_intf_conn_impl~get_source_data
          EXPORTING
            io_edocument   = io_edocument
          receiving
            rd_source_data = rd_source_data.

        IF io_edocument->ms_edocument-source_type = 'ISU_INVOIC'.
* Retrieve source document and map according to source type
          lo_source    = io_edocument->get_source( ).
          ls_src_header = lo_source->get_header( ).

          lo_source->get_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_isu_invoice ).

          lo_edocument_in ?= io_edocument.
          ls_source-reference-edoc_guid = lo_edocument_in->ms_edocument-edoc_guid.
          ls_source-source_header       = ls_src_header.
          ls_source-reference-edoc_guid = io_edocument->ms_edocument-edoc_guid.

          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOC_HEADER_ISU' OF STRUCTURE ls_source TO <fs_doc_header1>.
          IF <fs_doc_header1> IS ASSIGNED.

entry.title: Modernizing SAP HR-FIN Integration in Public Institutions: Scalable Employee-Vendor Migration in S/4
entry.content:
1. Background & Objective

In SAP ECC, the Employee Vendor master is a key component for enabling travel reimbursements. Typically created via transaction PRAA, these vendor records must be transformed into Business Partners (BPs) prior to any S/4HANA upgrade using the Software Update Manager (SUM).

This transformation is not just a technical necessity; it is a critical process for ensuring financial and operational continuity post-migration. The challenge is magnified in public sector environments where Concurrent Employment is common and not fully supported by SAP’s standard programs.

The goal of this initiative was to:

  • Ensure accurate and compliant migration of Employee Vendors to Employee BPs
  • Eliminate duplicate vendor records stemming from concurrent employment
  • Design a replicable, scalable, and SAP-aligned model that can benefit other public institutions across the U.S.
  1. Mandatory Enhancements in SAP ECC

A critical consideration in the ECC-to-S/4HANA migration is the assignment of the correct Business Partner category. Employee vendors must be migrated with Category 1 (Person). Initially, Employee BPs were incorrectly created with Category 2 (Organization). To resolve this, we implemented SAP Note 3362655 – "Mapping of the Business Partner Category as Person during Employee Vendor Migration", ensuring that the correct category was consistently applied.

With SAP S/4HANA 2021, a new Business Partner synchronization model is available via Business Function /SHCM/EE_BP_1/. In this model:

  • One BP with the Employee role represents the central person (CP)
  • One or more BPs with the Employment role represent individual contracts (PERNRs)

We utilized program /SHCM/R_EMPL_HANDLE_BPROLES to assign vendor roles to Employment BPs. However, in environments with Concurrent Employment, this standard logic assigns vendor roles to all assignments, including secondary ones—creating duplicate vendors and risking payment errors.

To address this, we enhanced the program to exclude Employment BPs for secondary assignments from vendor role mapping. This ensures that only the main assignment is eligible for travel payments and vendor role assignment.

  1. Migration of Employee Vendors in ECC

The MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT transaction was used to migrate employee vendors (ZEMPL) into Employee Business Partners. The same number range was maintained for both the Employee Vendor and the corresponding BP to ensure traceability and consistency.

  1. Configurations after SAP S/4HANA migration and before releasing the system to users:  

a. Business Function Activation

Per SAP recommendation, business function /SHCM/EE_BP_1 is activated in S/4HANA to support the New Business partner Model.

Characteristics of the new employee business partner model
• One business partner per central person with role Employee is created
• Separate business partners are created for every employment (every secondary assignment)
• Employment BP can have vendor or other roles assigned based on business requirement

b. Below config has been performed in the development system and then migrated along the landscape to production:

Table T77SO:

For HRALX-ESUBG=AB, we need to maintain the number range. Please see below section

c. Define Number Ranges

IMG-Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Number Ranges and Groupings.

d. Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges

IMG-Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner-> Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges.

Maintained AB number range:

e. Create Number Ranges for Vendor Accounts

IMG->Financial Accounting->Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable->Supplier Accounts->Master Data->Preparations for Creating Supplier Master Data-> Create Number Ranges for Vendor Accounts

f. Assign Number Ranges to Vendor Account Groups

IMG->Financial Accounting->Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable->Supplier Accounts->Master Data->Preparations for Creating Supplier Master Data-> Assign Number Ranges to Vendor Account Groups

Assign AB Number range to ZEMPL account group

g. Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Vendor

IMG Path- Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Field Assignment for Vendor Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Vendor

h. Define Number Assignment for Direction Vendor to BP

IMG Path- Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Field Assignment for Vendor Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction Vendor to BP

i. Define Address Types

Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Basic Settings->Address Determination->Define Address Types

Maintain HCM001 & HCM003

  • HCM001 Employee Private Address
  • HCM003 Address of Main Employment

j. Define Identification Types

Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Basic Settings ->Identification Numbers->Define Identification Types

Maintain HCM001, HCM032 and HCM033

  • HCM032 Personnel Number (Main Employment)
  • HCM033 Personnel Number (Employment)

 

k. Define BP Roles

IMG->Cross-Application Components ->SAP Business Partner ->Business Partner ->Basic Settings ->Define BP Roles.

 

l. Define Reconciliation Accounts for Employees in Role FI Supplier

IMG->Integration with Other SAP Components->Integration with SAP Success Factors (Employee Central)-> Define Reconciliation Accounts for Employees in Role FI Supplier.

m. PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC

Launch SM30 and enter table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC, also create a reference vendor in the development client and later this needs to be maintained in each client.

  1. Initial HR Sync in SAP S/4HANA

This report /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_EMPL_SINGLE must be executed before releasing the system to the users. This report is executed for all active and inactive employees:

  1. For pernrs with single employment- This report will create two BPs, one BP with employee role and another BP with employment role. 
  2. For pernrs with multiple employment- This report will create one BP with employee role and one or more employment role (for each secondary assignment, an employment BP will be created).  Post S/4HANA Employee Sync Jobs

After SAP S/4HANA GO-Live, report /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_FROM_EMPL must be scheduled in background. This report must run daily in production.

Note: when a new employee record is created, immediately system creates an employee BP and employment BP if the effective date = systems date. If the effective date is in future, this job /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_FROM_EMPL creates employee BP and employment BP based on effective date. Hence, it is essential to run this job daily.

  1. /SHCM/R_EMPL_HDLE_BPRLES_DELTA-Vendor Role Job

This job adds a vendor role-FLVN00 to an employment BP. This report reads the data from table-/SHCM/D_RLE_SYNC. This report should run in production on daily basis.

Important Note: Program /SHCM/R_EMPL_HANDLE_BPROLES also adds vendor role to selected Pernrs with employment BP. This program has a selection screen to enter the Pernr. This program can be executed on an exceptional basis. We have modified this program to skip the vendor role addition for secondary assignments (as mentioned earlier).

8. Enhancements in /SHCM/R_EMPL_HDLE_BPRLES_DELTA

Enhancement #1: If the report is mistakenly executed without a variant, this report can add vendor role to all employment BPs, hence an enhancement is added to run this job with Last sync date. An error message will be displayed to the users if this report is executed without Last sync date.

Enhancement#2: Since this report adds a vendor role to secondary assignment, an enhancement is needed to prevent the vendor role creation for secondary assignment. If a pernr in the table -/SHCM/D_RLE_SYNC is a secondary assignment, the enhancement will skip that pernr and vendor role will not be added.

Enhancement #3: An enhancement is done to modify the payment method and house bank information in employee vendor based on HR payment method and Bank information.

  1. Employee Business Partner Overview Report

The report /SHCM/R_EE_BP_RELATION_OVW (T.code-/SHCM/EE_BP_RLTN) provides a relationship between User, employee BP, employment BP and vendor #. This report can be executed with Pernr or Business Partner # or User ID.

  1. Troubleshooting Tips:
    1. Table BUT000- this table provides creation and modifications date and time stamp for employee BP and employment BP.
    2. SLG1 log to check all BP creation errors

Conclusion

This document demonstrates a complete, end-to-end strategy for employee vendor migration during SAP S/4HANA implementation. Through custom enhancements and targeted configuration, we aligned the migration with SAP best practices while addressing unique institutional needs such as Concurrent Employment.

The solution is scalable and applicable to other U.S.-based public institutions—ensuring reliable vendor synchronization, accurate travel payments, and reduced duplication in a highly regulated environment.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment
  • Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates
  • Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER
  • Simplified Data Integration
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Catena-X Certification
  • SAP Innovation Award Wins: Harting and Matsumoto Precision
  • Customer Success Story: DMK
  • SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

 

Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment

When integrating SAP Sustainability Footprint Management with various SAP systems, you often face a data challenge: Your warehouse in one SAP solution might be a facility in another or even a resource elsewhere. This inconsistency complicates footprint calculations, energy flow modeling, and linking environmental results to financials.

To address this and streamline and simplify the management of location data, we released the new Manage Locations application. This app serves as a single source for managing all locations, regardless of origin or business context. It addresses the need to reconcile and correlate locations that may have different semantics across multiple SAP solutions. With this new app you can:

  • View and manage all locations in one consolidated interface
  • Manually create locations or view those imported from other SAP modules
  • Easily distinguish between manually created and imported locations via the user interface
  • Navigate via links between imported location records and their corresponding system-generated system entries

Alternatively to replicating locations from source systems or creating them manually, you can upload location information via Excel files in the Import Master Data app. When importing, the software automatically generates corresponding location records that appear in the Manage Locations app – ensuring no duplicated or orphaned records. The locations itself are categorized into different location types, adding business context: Meter, Process Infrastructure, and Facility. Imported locations are automatically mapped to one of these three types. If a location type doesn’t match, it defaults to Facility. For modeling energy flows, you can now use these harmonized locations and resources as elements in your models. Hence, the creation of meters, process infrastructures, and facilities within the Model Energy Flows app is now managed exclusively via the new Manage Locations app – ensuring data consistency across apps.

Another major improvement is the possibility to assign cost centers for financial transparency and connecting carbon footprint results directly with your financial reporting. These assignments are time-dependent, ensuring correct mapping for each period. After calculating your organizational footprint, the Manage Footprint Results app shows the active cost center for that location – specifically, the cost center that is valid as of the calculation period’s start date, which is important if multiple cost centers are assigned to the location. Besides locations, cost centers can now also be assigned to energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. This enables better tracking of spending related to energy use and maintenance, helping to analyze and manage energy costs more effectively.

Click the picture to start the video:

Manage Locations App (Click to start video)

To summarize, these enhancements bring you a centralized, consistent interface for all location data with improved usability and a simplified integration across various SAP systems. The flexible cost center assignment enables the linkage of environmental data to financial entities. This empowers smarter and holistic decision-making in sustainability management, moving further along the journey towards ledger-based carbon accounting with SAP Green Ledger. For all details, see Manage Locations on SAP Help.

 

Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates

A common challenge for calculating Scope 1 and 2 emissions is the timely availability of energy bills needed for accurately recording energy consumption. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management addresses this by introducing more flexibility in how energy data can be captured. Now, when creating energy sources, you can select your preferred method for recording energy consumption, with the two available options:

  • Actual Consumption from Energy Bills: Enter the actual quantities consumed as detailed on your energy bills (the most accurate method).
  • Estimates via Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates: Add up amounts based on assigned meter readings and planned energy consumption rates, which allows you to work with estimates when bills are unavailable.

Select Recording of Energy Consumption

This new functionality isn’t limited to newly created energy sources. You can apply it to existing ones as well. However, it’s important to note that updating an energy source with this new logic doesn’t automatically trigger updates across all footprint inventories. If you edit the inventories that reference the updated energy source in their energy flow models, the system will recalculate using the newly selected consumption recording logic.

This release gives you the flexibility to maintain complete and more timely energy consumption records, improving the reliability of your sustainability data even when actual energy bills are delayed or not available at all. For more information, see the Energy Sources section under Model Energy Flows.

 

Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER

For calculating carbon footprints with no actual supplier or provider data available, it’s crucial to have access to reliable industry average data from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management provides you with the flexibility to upload respective data from any source into the Manage Emission Factors app. To simplify the setup for you and reduce manual efforts, we now added new default content, available for mapping your activities for calculating the respective footprints.

The data from UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (UK DEFRA) includes emission factors for energy use, water consumption, waste disposal, recycling, and transport activities. There are datasets available for the years 2015 to 2024.

EMBER, an independent energy think tank, provides emission factors for electricity generation for over 200 geographies. The datasets comprise the years 2015 to 2023.

Click the picture to start the video:

Default Emission Factors in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Click to start video)

With those enhancements, you have access to additional reliable and diverse data sources for better environmental impact analysis and decision-making. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data.

This new content complements the datasets from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) which were already added last year. And for the second half year we plan to add even more pre-configured emission factors from additional sources, further enhancing your carbon footprint calculation. The addition of emission factors was also one of the highest voted items on SAP Influence, requested by several customers and partners. Thanks to your valuable feedback, we’re constantly improving our product.

 

Simplified Data Integration

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduced significant enhancements to how sustainability data is imported and managed, making processes more simple, efficient, and user-friendly. The tool leverages the sustainability data integration service to streamline data import from SAP systems, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Environment, Health and Safety Management. This update eliminates many manual steps and unifies the process across systems. All changes are reflected in the updated SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Implementation Guide on SAP Help Portal.

With those enhancements, we’re also introducing the Manage Replications application. This new app allows you to configure and manage the replication of master data objects, such as products or suppliers, from multiple integrated SAP systems. Once replication is initiated through this app, imported data becomes visible in the Import Master Data app, simplifying subsequent data management tasks. The key benefits for you are:

  • Multi-source replication: Import master data from various source systems (for example fetch Products from SAP S/4HANA and Suppliers from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  • Centralized management: Oversee and control all data replications from one place.
  • Improved data consistency: Ensures data is harmonized and consistent, provided the correct source systems are chosen for each data object.
  • Filter records: For some of the entities, like Products, you can filter the source data objects so only the ones which are relevant in your footprint calculation are replicated.

To use the Manage Replications app, users must be manually assigned the roles: SUS_Replication_Viewer or SUS_Replication_Expert. Find further information as well as all details on the new app in SAP Help: Manage Replications.

Manage Replications App

For existing customers, the following changes are required:

  • Switch to Manage Replications App: The previous method of importing master data directly within the Import Master Data app is discontinued for integrated source systems. The Import button has been removed, and all such imports must now be managed through the new Manage Replications app.
  • SAP EHS Management Integration: All emissions management activities and locations must now be imported via the Manage Replications app.
  • Replication Details: When replicating Suppliers or Emission Management Activities, each replication now performs a complete import – incremental or delta updates are no longer supported for these entities.

Those updates vastly improve the efficiency and governance of sustainability data management within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, offering you a more powerful, secure, and streamlined experience when handling master data from multiple integrated sources.

 

Other Release Highlights

The Monitor Plausibility Checks app displays reference details of the item, period, and measure value used as the baseline for creating relative plausibility alerts. This helps you assess how much actual results deviate from expected calculations. For more information, see Monitor Plausibility Checks. This is also a feature that was implemented after numerous customers requested it via SAP Influence.

A new Generate Records button in the Manage Purchased Products Footprints app allows you to manually generate records for purchased products and product groups that lack footprints. Progress is displayed during record generation, and users are notified if records need to be regenerated due to data updates, ensuring accuracy and control. Additionally, the UI in the related tabs now labels the AI-assisted mapping button as Generate Mappings Using AI. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more details.

We achieved significant performance improvements in cycle calculations, where a process's output becomes its own input. Previously, the runtime increased with the cycle's complexity. Now, calculations are done in-memory rather than relying on database access, greatly reducing calculation time and improving user efficiency.

SAP now offers real-time machine translation for documentation on the SAP Help Portal, including SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This increases the number of available languages, improving accessibility and availability of product information for users worldwide.

To help you with onboarding and using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we’re also constantly enhancing the product documentation on SAP Help. In the previous quarter, this included the following topics:

  • Energy carrier assignment per internal service confirmation: The new topic in the Energy Distribution Scenarios section explains two different methods for assigning energy to production documents using data from internal service confirmations, see Energy Carrier Assignment per Internal Service Confirmation.
  • Modeling consistent energy flows: Useful guidance on using energy elements in flow models and explanations on how different components are connected, see Modeling Consistent Energy Flows.
  • Energy distribution scenarios: The updated explanation details how energy consumption and distribution are modeled via the energy flows, using planned rates, meter data, or both, see Energy Distribution Scenarios.
  • Importing master data for Products using file upload: An example explains how to enter data for quantity conversions and quantity dimensions, see the section Example: Quantity Conversions and Dimensions in Products.
  • Data Inconsistencies: Guidelines on addressing these issues, see Business Transaction Data Consistency for details.
  • Delete imported business transaction data: More details on how to handle this process, see Deleting Business Transaction Data.

 

Catena-X Certification

In Q2, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management successfully was Catena-X certified by Cofinity-X, as the first carbon calculation software to receive this certification. Catena-X is the automotive industry’s open, collaborative data ecosystem, designed to facilitate secure and standardized data exchange across the entire value chain. With this certification, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management meets the rigorous calculation, interoperability, and data sovereignty standards required by Catena-X, enabling customers to seamlessly calculate and share trustworthy carbon footprint and sustainability data with partners, suppliers, and customers in the ecosystem. This not only supports regulatory and customer-driven transparency requirements but also paves the way for scalable decarbonization efforts in the automotive industry and beyond. By aligning with Catena-X, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management empowers organizations to participate confidently in cross-company sustainability initiatives within a rapidly evolving digital value network. With the integration to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, carbon footprint data can be exchanged automatically and seamlessly.

 

Innovation Award Wins

We’re very proud to announce that two of our SAP Sustainability Footprint Management customers won the SAP Innovation Award 2025 in the Sustainability Hero category: Harting Technology Group and Matsumoto Precision!

Faced with the challenge of calculating carbon footprints for over 100,000 products across 14 factories, HARTING Technology Group needed a scalable, integrated solution. By becoming an early pilot customer of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, HARTING automated emissions tracking and achieved one-click carbon footprint calculations for 13,000 products – replacing a manual, time-consuming process. The solution, now live in three factories and expanding to all 14 by 2026, enables real-time, granular CO₂ data that supports HARTING’s “GreenLine” product label and helps meet stringent EU regulations like the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Digital Product Passport. Thanks to this innovation, HARTING can now report that 85% of its packaging materials are recycled, and it has a clear path to achieving net-zero operations by 2030. This collaboration with SAP not only enhances transparency and compliance but also gives HARTING a competitive edge in customer bids – proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand. Read the whole story here: HARTING - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

To address the growing demand for carbon transparency and operational efficiency, Matsumoto Precision implemented SAP S/4HANA alongside SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This combination gave the company real-time visibility into both product-level carbon emissions and profitability. With this data-driven approach, Matsumoto Precision was able to reduce its annual CO₂ emissions by 400 tons, increase productivity by 30 percent, and improve its operating profit margin by 3 percent. The factory now runs entirely on renewable energy, with on-site solar generation covering a significant portion of its needs. The implementation also empowered employees with real-time insights, leading to better decision-making and increased job satisfaction. Customers now receive verified carbon footprint data for each product, enhancing trust and supporting their own sustainability goals. In collaboration with Accenture, Matsumoto Precision even developed a generative AI tool that automates lifecycle flow diagrams, significantly reducing manual effort and streamlining emissions reporting. As CEO Toshitada Matsumoto put it, “With SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we make smarter, greener decisions while tracking and visualizing CO₂ emissions for each product. And with this clarity, we can enhance our brand value.” Matsumoto Precision’s journey is a compelling example of how small and mid-sized manufacturers can lead the way in sustainable innovation by embedding carbon intelligence into every layer of their operations. Read the full story here: Matsumoto Precision Co., Ltd. - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

 

Customer Success Story: DMK

Germany’s largest dairy cooperative, DMK Deutsches Milchkontor GmbH, is leading the way in sustainable food production. Processing over 5.3 billion kilograms of milk annually, DMK is committed to reducing its environmental impact across the value chain. With ambitious climate goals – including a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030 – DMK turned to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to bring transparency and precision to its carbon accounting.

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, DMK transformed how it calculates and manages product-level emissions. The solution enabled the company to move beyond industry averages and instead use granular, actual data to assess the carbon footprint of its milk-based products. This shift provided DMK with unprecedented transparency and accuracy, particularly in understanding and reporting Scope 3 emissions from its upstream value chain, such as milk production and transportation.

The digitalization of carbon footprint management not only helped DMK meet regulatory requirements but also strengthened its ability to respond to customer demands for credible, verifiable sustainability metrics. With SAP’s expert support and a tailored pilot program, DMK integrated emissions data directly into its product lifecycle, enabling more strategic decision-making and targeted decarbonization efforts.

This collaboration has positioned DMK as a leader in sustainable dairy production, demonstrating how digital tools can drive real progress toward climate goals while enhancing trust and transparency across the value chain. Read the full story here: DMK: Identifying the carbon footprint of milk-based products on the way to decarbonizing the value chain.

 

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP’s commitment to sustainability is integrated into its core mission of improving economic, social, and environmental outcomes while respecting planetary and human rights boundaries. SAP is actively using its own sustainability software solutions to meet environmental and social goals, demonstrating an “SAP runs SAP” and “customer zero” approach. By implementing tools like SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management within its operations, SAP treats sustainability management with the same rigor as financial reporting.

As a user, SAP faces challenges similar to its clients: collecting and managing large volumes of sustainability data, ensuring compliance with evolving regulations, and integrating data systems across the organization and supply chain. By implementing its sustainability solutions and continuously refining them through hands-on experience, SAP gains valuable insights that help improve its products for clients. Key lessons from their internal adoption include: ensuring consistent emissions data collection, grounding projects within governance frameworks, expanding focus beyond carbon to other environmental factors, and establishing a multi-layer data architecture for effective collection, processing, and reporting. The rollout of these systems is iterative, enabling refinement and adaptation—especially important as regulatory requirements change, such as the new EU Omnibus package. Overall, SAP aims to provide actionable sustainability insights, streamline ESG reporting, and drive both internal and customer progress toward measurable sustainability outcomes. To learn more, read the news article from Matthias Medert, SAP’s global head of Sustainability: SAP Runs Its Own Solutions for Sustainability Goals.

A central piece of the SAP runs SAP Sustainability IT architecture is SAP Sustainability Footprint Management:

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability - IT Architecture

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP has created a centralized and integrated platform to collect and calculate its corporate carbon emissions. The ambition is clear: to achieve full coverage of SAP’s carbon footprint through automated data collection and calculation. The software is much more than just a reporting tool, it acts as a central hub for emissions data, feeding into other SAP sustainability solutions such as the SAP Green Ledger, the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and various internal systems. This enables comprehensive environmental impact analysis and supports regulatory compliance, while also informing strategic business decisions. Currently, SAP has already validated around 50% of its corporate carbon footprint within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This includes emissions from its own facilities like offices and data centers, as well as from shared infrastructure, cloud providers, and purchased goods and services.

The journey hasn’t been without challenges. At the outset, SAP faced difficulties in gathering and harmonizing data from multiple sources, each managed by different internal teams. Some of the data also required enrichment to be usable for sustainability purposes. However, through close collaboration between internal IT and business units, these hurdles were largely overcome, resulting in a more consistent and unified data flow.

Looking ahead, SAP aims to expand the system’s coverage to 100% of its corporate carbon footprint (excluding downstream emissions) before the planned business go-live in Q3. This milestone will involve five company codes and marks a significant step toward embedding sustainability deeper into SAP’s operations. All of this is being achieved through a continuous co-innovation process with SAP’s sustainability product engineering teams, demonstrating how SAP isn’t only building tools for others but also using them to lead by example. For all details, read the paper SAP runs SAP Sustainability: How to unlock the Power of Data on Sustainability Goals at Scale.

 

Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

The new Learning Journey Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is the first one that focuses on Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) calculation. The one-hour self-learning is as all our Learning Journeys free of charge and targets consultants and business users with advanced product knowledge. Additional Information

With a practical example, she explains how to track carbon throughout business processes and incorporate sustainability into operations.
